Title: How to prove the sum of squares is minimum?
Content:
Given $n$ nonnegative values. Their sum is $k$.
$$
x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n = k
$$
The sum of their squares is defined as:
$$
x_1^2 + x_2^2 + \cdots + x_n^2
$$ I think that the sum of squares is minimum when $x_1 = x_2 = \cdots = x_n$. But I can't figure out how to prove it. Can anybody help me on this? Thanks.
AcceptedAnswer: HINT : By Cauchy-Schwarz we know $$\left(\sum x_i y_i\right)^2 \leq \left(\sum x_i^2\right) \left(\sum y_i^2\right)$$ Take $y_i = 1$ for all $i$ to get a lower bound on $\sum x_i^2$. Then show that $x_i = \frac{k}{n}$ achieves this bound.
